1,4-butanediol serves as a crucial monomeric building block for the production of biodegradable plastics such as PBS and PBAT, and it can also be utilized for the synthesis of derivatives like γ-butyrolactone and tetrahydrofuran. The technology of direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to 1,4-butanediol over Cu-ZnO has emerged as a promising production method due to its advantages of a short process flow, mild reaction conditions, cost-effective catalysts, and the capability to co-produce various products. However, at the current stage, the reaction kinetic equations and optimal conditions for 1,4-butanediol formation via direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride over Cu-ZnO remain unclear, which hinders the development of this production process. In this study, based on the findings of density functional theory, this study investigated the reaction kinetics of direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride on Cu211 surfaces and at Cu211-ZnO interfaces using activity evaluation experiments and kinetic Monte Carlo simulations. Through activity evaluation experiments of direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, this study examined the effects of temperature, pressure, and hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio on product formation over Cu-ZnO catalysts and identified the optimal reaction conditions for 1,4-butanediol production as 200 °C, 2 MPa, and a hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio of 150. Utilizing the kinetic Monte Carlo method, this study calculated the reaction processes for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to γ-butyrolactone on Cu211 surfaces and to γ-butyrolactone, 1,4-butanediol, and tetrahydrofuran at Cu211-ZnO interfaces. The optimal reaction conditions for the formation of maleic anhydride to γ-butyrolactone, 1,4-butanediol, and tetrahydrofuran were obtained, respectively. Finally, intrinsic reaction kinetic equations for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to different products were fitted and derived. The obtained intrinsic reaction kinetic equations can be applied in the design of actual reactors or process development after considering the influence of diffusion or directly used in studies where diffusion effects are insignificant. This provides a design foundation for the construction of production processes for direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to 1,4-butanediol over Cu-ZnO. It is hoped that this study can offer insights and guidance for the understanding of the direct hydrogenation process of maleic anhydride and the development of the biodegradable plastics industry. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Maleic anhydride 1,4-butanediol Cu-ZnO Reaction kinetic Activity evaluation experiments kinetic Monte Carlo Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction 1,4-Butanediol (BDO) serves as a crucial raw material for the production of poly butylene succinate (PBS), poly butylene terephthalate (PBT), Poly butylene adipate-co-terephthalate (PBAT), and poly tetrahydrofuran (PTMEG), among others [1–4]. It is highly favored in the fields of biodegradable plastics and fibers. Industrially, there are primarily four production processes for BDO. Among them, the Reppe process, Lyondell process, and Mitsubishi process are constrained by environmental concerns, production economics, and raw material supply issues. In contrast, the maleic anhydride (MA) hydrogenation process has been gaining a larger market share due to its advantages such as a straightforward technological process, mild reaction conditions, and the capability to co-produce multiple products [5–7]. Among the more mature production technologies for 1,4-butanediol through maleic anhydride hydrogenation are the Geminox technology [8,9] and the Davy-Mackee technology [10–12]. In addition, a highly promising process is the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, which involves the direct gas-phase or liquid-phase hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce 1,4-butanediol. Compared to the Geminox and Davy-Mackee technologies, the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride offers a shorter process flow, avoids the ester exchange side reactions common in the Davy-Mackee process, and mitigates the severe corrosion of equipment by acids in the Geminox process. Catalysts commonly used in the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride are Cu-based and Ni-based catalysts, which are relatively inexpensive. Furthermore, by adjusting the reaction conditions, this process can co-produce 1,4-butanediol, tetrahydrofuran (THF), and γ-butyrolactone (GBL), making it a technology with broad application prospects [13,14]. Among the extensive research on direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, Cu-based catalysts have been the most thoroughly studied. Cu-based catalysts are inexpensive, easily obtainable, and simple to prepare, exhibiting good activity and selectivity for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride [15–20]. Notably, Cu-ZnO catalysts demonstrate excellent catalytic activity for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce 1,4-butanediol [21–24]. Previous studies have elucidated the reaction mechanism, types of by-products, and formation pathways of 1,4-butanediol from maleic anhydride over Cu-ZnO using density functional theory (DFT) [25]. However, to develop a process for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to 1,4-butanediol, optimal reaction conditions and reaction kinetic equations tailored for BDO production are necessary. Gerhard et al. [26] proposed two distinct reaction pathways for the hydrogenation of succinic anhydride (SA) to γ-butyrolactone over copper/zinc catalysts and developed kinetic models for both pathways. They considered power-law rate expressions for the reversible adsorption of succinic anhydride on the zinc oxide surface and its diffusion to the adjacent copper microcrystallites, which were suitable for describing the experimental data. Gerhard et al. [27]. also prepared a series of binary Cu-ZnO catalysts with copper-to-zinc ratios ranging from 0.1 to 9.0 and applied them in kinetic measurements conducted in a stirred three-phase slurry reactor. Through model identification, they obtained a detailed kinetic model for the hydrogenation of succinic anhydride over Cu-ZnO catalysts, considering the reversible carbon balance losses observed experimentally. At present, there is still a lack of reaction kinetic equations for the direct hydrogenation of MA to BDO over Cu-ZnO and suitable conditions for BDO production. This undoubtedly limits the development of production processes for BDO via the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride. This study builds on the elementary reaction data for the direct hydrogenation of MA to BDO over Cu-ZnO obtained from previous DFT research. By utilizing kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) methods and activity evaluation experiments, this study aim to identify suitable reaction conditions for the direct hydrogenation of MA to BDO and fit intrinsic reaction kinetic equations for the production of different products from maleic anhydride. This will provide a design foundation for the construction of production processes for the direct hydrogenation of MA to BDO over Cu-ZnO. It is hoped that this study can offer insights and guidance for the understanding of the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride process and the development of the biodegradable plastics industry. 2 Computational and experimental methods 2.1 Experimental methods The catalyst utilized in this study is a commercial CuO-ZnO-Al₂O₃ catalyst with a composition of 70 wt% CuO and 24.5 wt% ZnO. The reduction conditions for the catalyst are as follows: Firstly, the catalyst is heated to 120 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atmosphere and maintained at this temperature for 2 h. Subsequently, it is exposed to a 10v% H2/Ar atmosphere for 1 hour. Afterward, the temperature is increased to 196 °C at a rate of 1 °C/min under an H2/Ar atmosphere and maintained at this temperature for an additional hour. Finally, the catalyst is heated to the reaction temperature under an N₂ atmosphere. The evaluation of the direct hydrogenation reactivity of maleic anhydride was conducted in a fixed-bed high-pressure microreactor system, as illustrated in Fig. 1 . The apparatus primarily consists of gas feed, liquid feed, reaction system, and cold trap system components. The gases involved include a 10v% H2/Ar mixture for catalyst activation, N₂ for purging and protection, and high-purity H2 for the reaction. The reaction feedstock is a mixture of 20 wt% maleic anhydride in tetrahydrofuran, which is introduced into the system via a high-pressure constant-flow pump. The reaction system comprises a high-pressure microreactor system featuring a tubular furnace and a tubular reactor made of Hastelloy HC276. The cold trap system, maintained at −5 °C using a circulating chilled ethylene glycol solution, is employed to collect the liquid products within the system. The collected products from the cold trap are sent to a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) system for component content analysis. The models of the instruments and equipment used in this setup are listed in Table S1. 2.2 Computational methods 2.2.1 Computational model The kinetic Monte Carlo simulations utilize a lattice model [28,29], where a two-dimensional square periodic grid of 128 × 128 lattice points is employed to represent the Cu surface. Based on previously developed density functional theory models of the Cu211 surface and Cu211-ZnO interface [25], kMC models for these surfaces and interfaces were constructed, as illustrated in Fig. 2 . The Cu211 surface has a unit cell with dimensions a = 19.25 Å, b = 10.48 Å, c = 20.29 Å, and α=β=γ=90°, containing 96 Cu atoms. The DFT model of the Cu211-ZnO interface involves a ZnO cluster Zn6O7H7 supported on the Cu211 surface, consisting of 7 H atoms, 7 O atoms, 96 Cu atoms, and 6 Zn atoms. Based on the DFT models, the constructed kMC models have a surface area of 201.74 Å2. For the kMC model of Cu211, the adsorption sites include 27 top sites, 72 bridge sites, and 45 hollow sites. For the kMC model of the Cu211-ZnO interface, the adsorption sites include 18 top sites, 48 bridge sites, 30 hollow sites, and 1 adsorption site for the ZnO cluster. 2.2.2 Computational settings Based on the optimal reaction conditions for 1,4-butanediol production obtained from the activity evaluation experiments for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, kMC calculations were conducted under the conditions of P = 2 MPa, T = 473 K, and a hydrogen-to-anhydride molar ratio (H2/MA) of 150. Upon testing, it was observed that the formation of various species stabilized when the simulation duration reached 0.1 s. In these calculations, the adsorption of H2 was defined as dissociative adsorption. The formulas for calculating the adsorption rate coefficients of MA and H2 on the Cu211 surface and Cu211-ZnO interface are presented in Eqs. (1) and 2, respectively [30]. (1) k MA = σ P A site 2 π m k B T (2) k H 2 = σ P A site 2 2 π m k B T In the equation, σ is the dimensionless sticking coefficient, typically set to 1 in kMC simulations [31–33]. In previous kinetic Monte Carlo studies conducted on Cu surfaces, involving gaseous reactants such as CO [34], H2O [35], and H2 [36], the sticking coefficient was assumed to be 1 (indicating complete adsorption). Similarly, for other types of reactions, including propylene adsorption on Au [31], acetylene and ethylene adsorption on Pd and Pd-Au [32], and CO adsorption on Pd[33], the sticking coefficient was also treated as 1. P represents the partial pressure of the adsorbing species. A site is the adsorption area per individual adsorption site, which can be derived by dividing the total surface area by the number of adsorption sites. m denotes the molecular mass of the adsorbing species. k B is Boltzmann's constant, and T represents the reaction temperature. The kMC calculations on the Cu211 surface involve two adsorption processes for MA and H2, seven desorption processes for MA, H2, succinic anhydride (SA), GBL, BDO, H2O, and THF, and 32 reaction processes corresponding to 16 reversible reactions. At the Cu211-ZnO interface, the kMC calculations encompass two adsorption processes for MA and H2, seven desorption processes for MA, H2, SA, GBL, BDO, H2O, and THF, and 44 reaction processes corresponding to 22 reversible reactions. The pre-exponential factors and activation energies for each elementary reaction step in the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to 1,4-butanediol on the Cu211 surface and at the Cu211-ZnO interface are presented in Tables 1 and 2 , respectively [25]. For the reaction, migration, and desorption processes, the reaction rate constants are all calculated using the Arrhenius equation: (3) k = Aexp ( − E a k B T ) In the equation, A represents the pre-exponential factor, E a is the activation energy of the elementary reaction calculated by DFT, k B is the Boltzmann constant, and T is the Kelvin temperature. The pre-exponential factor for each elementary reaction process is calculated using Eq. (4) [37]. (4) A = ∏ i = 1 3 n v i IS ∏ i = 1 3 n − 1 v i TS In the equation, v i IS is the vibrational frequency of the initial state of the reaction, v i TS is the vibrational frequency of the transition state (excluding imaginary frequencies), and n is the number of atoms in the reactants. The activation energy for each elementary reaction process is calculated using the following formula. (5) E a , f = E a (6) E a , r = E a − E r In the equation, E a , f represents the activation energy for the forward reaction, E a , r represents the activation energy for the inverse reaction, and E r is the reaction energy of the elementary reaction calculated by DFT. Regarding the calculations at the Cu211-ZnO interface, each ZnO site is well-separated by Cu sites. Therefore, for molecules adsorbed on Zn sites, the influence of their lateral interactions on reaction activation energies can be neglected[38]. On the Cu211 surface, it was observed during the calculations that the surface was heavily covered with H species. Due to this extensive coverage of H, incorporating interactions between H and all other species would significantly increase the computational cost. Furthermore, interactions between H species and other species are relatively weak. Thus, only interactions between strongly adsorbed species and nearby H atoms were considered [39]. Lateral interactions play a role by modifying the activation energies of all processes involved [40]. (7) E a 0 = E a + α E i n t e r = E a + α ( E r 0 − E r ) In the presence (or absence) of adsorbate interactions, the activation energy barriers are denoted as E a 0 ( E a ), E r 0 ( E r ) represent the reaction heats in the presence (or absence) of such interactions. The parameter α mentioned here refers to the Brønsted-Polanyi coefficient. Typically, for desorption processes, α = 1; for adsorption processes, α = 0; and for diffusion and reaction processes, α = 0.5 [41]. The interaction energy ( E i n t e r ) is approximately obtained by calculating the change in adsorption energy of an adsorbate when another adsorbate is nearby. Using density functional theory, the interaction energies between H species and maleic anhydride, succinic anhydride, γ-butyrolactone, and 1,4-butanediol were calculated to be 0.07 eV, 0.02 eV, 0.05 eV, and 0.05 eV, respectively. The turnover frequency (TOF) of elementary reactions obtained through kMC calculations is expressed in units of events/(site·s), which can be abbreviated as s-1. However, the unit commonly used in experiments is mol/(gcat·s), necessitating a unit conversion. The literature reports that the surface area of Cu atoms on Cu-Zn catalysts is 26 m2/g [42]. Therefore, the TOF in units of mol/(gcat·s) can be calculated as follows: TOF (mol/(gcat·s)) = TOF (events/(site·s)) × 4.282 × 10–4. 3 Research results 3.1 Activity evaluation of the direct hydrogenation reaction of maleic anhydride Utilizing the activity evaluation setup for direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, the process was investigated under conditions of temperatures ranging from 190 to 220 °C, pressures varying from 0.1 to 4.0 MPa, and hydrogen-to-anhydride ratios of 50–200. The conversions of maleic anhydride and the selectivities of the products under different pressures, temperatures, and hydrogen-to-anhydride ratios are shown in Table S2 in the Supporting Information. Figs. 3 , 4 , and 5 , which were plotted based on the data in Table S2, were used to explore the effects of pressure, temperature, and hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio, respectively, on the direct hydrogenation process of maleic anhydride. Fig. 3 displays the changes in product composition as a function of pressure within the range of 0.1–4.0 MPa. It can be observed from Fig. 3 that low pressure favors the formation of GBL, while 2 MPa is the optimal pressure for BDO production, and 3 MPa is suitable for THF generation. For the minor by-products, propionic acid is produced at low pressures, while butanol (BuOH) and propanol are more likely to form at pressures between 2 and 3 MPa. Fig. 4 illustrates the changes in product composition with temperature in the range of 190–220 °C. It is evident from Fig. 4 that high temperatures are conducive to THF production, with 200 °C being the optimal temperature for BDO generation. GBL's formation is relatively sensitive to temperature changes within this range. Regarding the minor by-products, high temperatures promote the production of butanol and propionic acid, while propanol and water are less affected by temperature variations. Fig. 5 shows the changes in product composition as the hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio varies between 50 and 200. According to Fig. 5, a low hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio favors THF production, with GBL formation being optimal at lower ratios and BDO production being optimal at higher ratios. When the hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio is 100, the production of other by-products such as butanol and propanol increases relatively. In summary, the formation of GBL tends to favor low pressure and low hydrogen-to-anhydride ratios, BDO production prefers lower temperatures, high pressures, and high hydrogen-to-anhydride ratios, and THF generation is more likely at high temperatures and pressures. These findings are generally consistent with the optimal conditions mentioned in the Davy company's process for producing BDO through maleic anhydride esterification and hydrogenation [43]. Based on the comprehensive analysis of Table S2 and Figs. 3, 4, and 5, it can be concluded that BDO, GBL, and THF are produced in relatively high yields, while propionic acid, butanol, propanol, and water are produced in lower amounts. Under most conditions, the species can be ranked in terms of their production yields as follows: GBL > BDO > THF, and butanol > propanol > propionic acid > water. With the focus on maximizing BDO production, the evaluation test for direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride has identified the optimal conditions for BDO synthesis as 200 °C, 2 MPa, and a hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio of 150. These findings will provide valuable reference and support for setting the initial conditions and performing simulation calculations in kMC modeling. 3 2 kMC calculation 3.2.1 Derivation of the reaction kinetic equations for the direct hydrogenation process of maleic anhydride In the study of heterogeneous catalytic reaction kinetics, the assumptions of steady-state approximation and rate-determining step are widely adopted. The steady-state approximation assumes that, once the reaction process reaches a steady state, the concentrations of intermediate compounds remain constant over time. The selection of the rate-determining step can be based on DFT calculations. Utilizing the assumptions of steady-state approximation and rate-determining step, along with the application of mass action law and Langmuir adsorption isotherm, the reaction kinetics equations can be derived from the predefined elementary reaction steps. Calculations of adsorption and desorption rate coefficients reveal that the adsorption and desorption processes in the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride are extremely fast, indicating that the entire reaction process is controlled by the surface reaction rate. Taking the reaction process of MA to GBL on Cu211 surface as an example, the form of the reaction kinetics equation for MA to GBL conversion is derived. The specific derivation process is outlined in Table 3 . In the table, * represents an adsorption site, MA* represents MA adsorbed on the catalyst surface, θ represents surface coverage, θ v represents uncovered surface fraction, and k is the adsorption rate constant. k → and k ← are the forward and reverse reaction rate constants, respectively, while r denotes the reaction rate. Similarly, the basic forms of the reaction kinetics equations for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce γ-butyrolactone, 1,4-butanediol, and tetrahydrofuran at the Cu211-ZnO interface can be derived, as shown in Table 4 . Subsequently, kinetic Monte Carlo simulations are employed to first determine the suitable reaction conditions for BDO formation. Then, the influence of reactant partial pressures on product formation rates under optimal reaction conditions is investigated. Finally, the intrinsic reaction kinetics equations for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to different products are obtained through fitting. 3.2.2 Reaction kinetics of the direct hydrogenation process of maleic anhydride on Cu211 surface Firstly, the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride on the Cu211 surface was investigated using the kinetic Monte Carlo method. It was observed that the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride on Cu211 exclusively produced γ-butyrolactone, without the formation of 1,4-butanediol or tetrahydrofuran. This finding is consistent with the conclusions derived from density functional theory calculations [25]. Subsequently, the variation in GBL formation rate was studied within a range of reaction conditions: temperatures of 413–553 K, pressures of 100–400 kPa, and H2/MA ratios of 25–400. This analysis allowed for the determination of the optimal reaction conditions for GBL production. The effects of temperature, pressure, and hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio on the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to GBL on the Cu211 surface are illustrated in Fig. 6 , with specific data provided in Supplementary Table S3. From Fig. 6(a), it can be observed that the production of GBL increases as the temperature rises, and the production of GBL tends to stabilize when the temperature reaches 513 K. Fig. 6(b) reveals that, overall, the production of GBL increases with an increasing hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio. However, in terms of numerical changes, the impact of the hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio on GBL production is much less significant than that of temperature. Despite an increase in the hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio from 25 to 400, the change in GBL production is relatively small, and excessively high ratios can significantly increase industrial loads. Therefore, a hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio of approximately 75–100 is sufficient to meet the requirements for high production and low load. Fig. 6(c) shows that the production of GBL decreases slightly as pressure increases. Considering industrial practice, atmospheric pressure is sufficient for GBL production. In summary, the optimal reaction conditions for GBL production on Cu211 are 513 K, a hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio of 75, and atmospheric pressure. Therefore, the kinetic study of the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to GBL on Cu211 was conducted at 513 K and atmospheric pressure. Table 5 presents the effects of partial pressures of maleic anhydride and hydrogen on the GBL formation rate at 513 K. Table 6 shows the impact of temperature on the GBL formation rate at atmospheric pressure and a hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio of 75. The data in Table 5 are primarily used to fit the coefficient preceding the pressure term in the kinetic equation, while the data in Table 6 are used to fit the pre-exponential factor and activation energy of the reaction. Using the data from Tables 5 and 6, the intrinsic reaction kinetics equation for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to γ-butyrolactone on Cu211 surface was fitted as: r GBL = 6.294 × 10 − 3 e ( − 22809.50 R T ) ( p MA p H 2 1.5 − 1.980 × 10 4 p GBL p H 2 O p H 2 1.5 ) ( 1 + 1.422 p MA + 1.367 p H 2 + 1.011 p GBL + 1.119 p H 2 O ) 2 . From the kinetic equation, it can be inferred that the activation energy for the direct hydrogenation of MA to GBL on Cu211 surface is 22.809 kJ/mol, indicating that the reaction is relatively easy to occur under optimal reaction conditions. 3.2.3 Reaction kinetics of the direct hydrogenation process of maleic anhydride at the Cu211-ZnO interface Based on the optimal conditions for 1,4-butanediol production derived from the activity evaluation experiments for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, kinetic Monte Carlo calculations were performed for the direct hydrogenation process at the Cu211-ZnO interface. The kMC results indicate that at the Cu211-ZnO interface, GBL, BDO, and THF are all produced, which is consistent with the conclusions obtained from density functional theory calculations [25]. Therefore, the variations in the production yields of the main products, GBL, BDO, and THF, were investigated within the ranges of 413–553 K, hydrogen-to-anhydride ratios of 25–450, and pressures of 100–5000 kPa. These results are illustrated in Fig. 7 , with specific data provided in Supplementary Tables S4, S5, and S6. From Fig. 7(a), it is evident that temperature has a much greater impact on GBL production compared to BDO and THF. When the temperature exceeds 513 K, the production yields of all three products decrease, indicating that excessively high temperatures are detrimental to the overall reaction. Since the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride is a strongly exothermic reaction, from a thermodynamic perspective, lower temperatures are more favorable for the reaction to proceed. Within the temperature range of 483–513 K, the production of GBL is relatively high. For BDO production, when the temperature is above 463 K, the production yield of BDO remains at a relatively high level. Overall, an increase in temperature favors the production of THF. Considering energy conservation in industrial settings, 493 K is identified as the optimal temperature for THF production. Fig. 7(b) shows that an increase in the hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio has a significant promotional effect on the production of both GBL and BDO, while THF experiences only minor changes. When the H2/MA ratio is around 150, the production of GBL reaches a high level. Although the production of GBL continues to increase when the H2/MA ratio exceeds 300, the increase is not significant compared to that at an H2/MA ratio of 150, and it significantly increases production loads. Therefore, an H2/MA ratio of around 150 is considered optimal for GBL production. The production of BDO increases continuously with an increasing H2/MA ratio, but considering production loads, an H2/MA ratio of around 200 maintains BDO production at a high level. The influence of the H2/MA ratio on THF production is not significant, and a lower H2/MA ratio can be selected under the same conditions. From Fig. 7(c), it can be observed that as pressure increases, the production of GBL decreases significantly, while the production of BDO and THF increases. Therefore, low or atmospheric pressure is favorable for GBL production, while high pressure favors the production of BDO and THF. However, excessively high pressure increases the requirements for equipment and production loads. Thus, a pressure of 2 MPa is suitable for the production of BDO and THF. Overall, the production yields of products from the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride at the Cu211-ZnO interface follow the order: GBL>BDO>THF. In summary, the optimal reaction conditions for the direct hydrogenation of MA to produce GBL at the Cu211-ZnO interface are 483 K, 101.325 kPa, and an H2/MA ratio of 150. The optimal conditions for BDO production are 463 K, 2 MPa, and an H2/MA ratio of 200. The optimal conditions for THF production are 493 K, 2 MPa, and an H2/MA ratio of 50. Since this study focuses on producing more 1,4-butanediol, the kinetic study of the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce GBL, BDO, and THF at the Cu211-ZnO interface will be conducted under the conditions of 463 K and 2 MPa. Table 7 presents the effects of partial pressures of maleic anhydride and hydrogen on the formation rates of γ-butyrolactone, 1,4-butanediol, and tetrahydrofuran at 463 K and 2 MPa. Table 8 shows the influence of temperature on the formation rates of GBL, BDO, and THF when the pressure is maintained at 2 MPa and the hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio is set to 200. Table 9 displays the intrinsic reaction kinetic equations obtained through fitting for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce GBL, BDO, and THF at the Cu211-ZnO interface. The intrinsic reaction kinetic equations in Table 9 reveal that the activation energies for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce GBL, BDO, and THF are 15.458 kJ/mol, 34.991 kJ/mol, and 48.799 kJ/mol, respectively. This indicates that, in terms of reaction ease, GBL is the easiest to form, followed by BDO, and then THF. However, numerically, the activation energies for the formation of all three products are relatively low, suggesting that the reactions can occur readily under the reaction conditions. This aligns with the predictions made by density functional theory regarding the ease of product formation [25]. According to the previous section, the activation energy for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce GBL on the Cu211 surface is 22.809 kJ/mol, whereas the activation energy at the Cu211-ZnO interface is 15.458 kJ/mol. This suggests that the introduction of ZnO facilitates the reaction process for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce GBL. 4 Conclusion This study, grounded in the findings of density functional theory, investigates the reaction kinetics of the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride on the Cu211 surface and at the Cu211-ZnO interface using activity evaluation experiments and kinetic Monte Carlo methods. Through activity evaluation experiments for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, the effects of temperature, pressure, and hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio on product formation over Cu-ZnO catalysts were examined. The optimal reaction conditions for the highest BDO yield were determined to be 200 °C, 2 MPa, and a hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio of 150. With reference to these optimal reaction conditions obtained from the activity evaluation experiments, the initial conditions for kMC calculations were set and the calculations initiated. The kMC method was utilized to separately calculate the reaction processes for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce GBL on the Cu211 surface and the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce GBL, BDO, and THF at the Cu211-ZnO interface. The optimal reaction conditions for the formation of GBL, BDO, and THF from MA were obtained, respectively. Finally, intrinsic reaction kinetic equations for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to different products were fitted and derived. The intrinsic reaction kinetic equations obtained in this study, when considering the influence of diffusion, can be applied in practical reactor design or process development, or directly used in research where diffusion effects are minimal. It is hoped that this study will provide guidance and assistance for the research on the reaction process of maleic anhydride hydrogenation to produce 1,4-butanediol and contribute to the development of the biodegradable plastics field. coredata.dc:description: 1,4-butanediol serves as a crucial monomeric building block for the production of biodegradable plastics such as PBS and PBAT, and it can also be utilized for the synthesis of derivatives like γ-butyrolactone and tetrahydrofuran. The technology of direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to 1,4-butanediol over Cu-ZnO has emerged as a promising production method due to its advantages of a short process flow, mild reaction conditions, cost-effective catalysts, and the capability to co-produce various products. However, at the current stage, the reaction kinetic equations and optimal conditions for 1,4-butanediol formation via direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride over Cu-ZnO remain unclear, which hinders the development of this production process. In this study, based on the findings of density functional theory, this study investigated the reaction kinetics of direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride on Cu211 surfaces and at Cu211-ZnO interfaces using activity evaluation experiments and kinetic Monte Carlo simulations. Through activity evaluation experiments of direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, this study examined the effects of temperature, pressure, and hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio on product formation over Cu-ZnO catalysts and identified the optimal reaction conditions for 1,4-butanediol production as 200 °C, 2 MPa, and a hydrogen-to-anhydride ratio of 150. Utilizing the kinetic Monte Carlo method, this study calculated the reaction processes for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to γ-butyrolactone on Cu211 surfaces and to γ-butyrolactone, 1,4-butanediol, and tetrahydrofuran at Cu211-ZnO interfaces. The optimal reaction conditions for the formation of maleic anhydride to γ-butyrolactone, 1,4-butanediol, and tetrahydrofuran were obtained, respectively. Finally, intrinsic reaction kinetic equations for the direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to different products were fitted and derived. The obtained intrinsic reaction kinetic equations can be applied in the design of actual reactors or process development after considering the influence of diffusion or directly used in studies where diffusion effects are insignificant. This provides a design foundation for the construction of production processes for direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to 1,4-butanediol over Cu-ZnO. It is hoped that this study can offer insights and guidance for the understanding of the direct hydrogenation process of maleic anhydride and the development of the biodegradable plastics industry.
